importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article publication indicates the current state of global disaster preparedness and climate action as of mid-October 2025.
The glacier collapse in the Swiss village of Blatten was predicted in May 2025, highlighting a real-time success of early warning systems in mitigating a localized disaster.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on current global weather disasters and the urgent need for early warning systems in 2025, reflecting a worsening trend of extreme weather due to climate change.

The ongoing weather-related disasters in 2025, such as floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, illustrate the immediacy of the crisis and the need for global monitoring.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries.
Over the past 50 years, weather, water, and climate-related hazards have killed over 2 million people.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning early warning websites and standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action—this is central to the WMO’s mission of empowering communities to respond effectively.
A real-world example of effective early warning: the prediction of a mountain glacier collapse in Switzerland in May 2025 allowed evacuation of the village of Blatten, preventing loss of life.
Permafrost melt and glacier instability are expected to increase rockfalls and collapses, making early warning systems increasingly vital.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has called for urgent global improvements in early-warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of all countries lack such systems—particularly in developing nations where disaster-related deaths are six times higher. Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years, with 90% of those deaths in developing countries. While global monitoring has improved, with 108 countries now using some form of early warnings (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity. The situation is most dire in conflict-affected and fragile regions. Progress is being seen in Africa, and real-world successes—such as the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, in May 2025 due to a predicted glacier collapse—demonstrate the life-saving potential of timely alerts. The WMO emphasizes that early warning enables early action, and with climate change intensifying weather extremes, such systems are essential for protecting lives and infrastructure worldwide.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
